docs.lead_paragraph: Naomi Batya Blumberg and Rabbi Braham Mazin David are to be married today at Temple Shir Tikva in Wayland, Mass. Rabbi Herman Blumberg, the bride's father, who is the senior rabbi at Temple Shir Tikva, will officiate with Rabbi Sion David, the bridegroom's father. The bride, 39, is an international public health specialist at the Bureau for Global Health at the Agency for International Development in Washington. She graduated from Brandeis and received a master's degree in public health from Boston University. Her mother, Paula Blumberg, is a clinical social worker in Canton, Mass. She and the bride's father live in Newton, Mass.

docs.lead_paragraph: THIS economic recovery is distinctly unkind to workers. Output is clearly rising, and, normally, that would feed into both corporate profits and labor income. But while profits have shot up as a percentage of national income, reaching their highest level since the mid-1960's, labor's share is shrinking. Not since World War II has the distribution been so lopsided in the aftermath of a recession.

headline.main: A Recovery For Profits, But Not for Workers

docs.abstract: Louis Uchitelle column holds current economic recovery is unkind to workers, with corporate profits soaring as percentage of national income and labor's share shrinking; notes profits rose as share of national income all through 2001 recession and months afterward of weak economic growth, trend that continued when recovery kicked in strongly in summer and hiring resumed; notes average wages of lower-paid workers are rising just fast enough to keep up with current mild inflation; holds labor has grown too weak to prevent many companies from pocketing virtually all of gains from increased productivity; graph of rising corporate earnings (M)
docs.snippet: THIS economic recovery is distinctly unkind to workers.      Output is clearly rising, and, normally, that would feed into both corporate profits and labor income. But while profits have shot up as a percentage of national income, reaching their...

docs.lead_paragraph: COTTON--Harvard A. 93, of Whitestone, NY, on December 19. Deeply mourned by his son Ross, his brother-inlaw and sister-in-law Bill and Betty Ruder and a warm and caring family of nieces, nephews and friends. Harvey was an extraordinary husband to his departed wife, Deborah, an inspiring high school math teacher in New York for over 35 years and a former President of Temple Hillel in Whitestone. His beautiful garden reflected a deep love of nature and sense of aesthetics. He conceived of, formed and managed S.H.I.P., the Supplemental Health Insurance Program for retired teachers that became a department of the UFT. We all will sorely miss him. Services are private.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths   COTTON, HARVARD A.

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN the Suozzi administration took office in January 2002, it tackled Nassau County's budget crisis by reducing the county workforce by 1,100, enacting efficiencies that saved $100 million and negotiating labor contracts that it said held the line on costs. But almost two years of budget-tightening could be undone by huge increases in state-mandated pension and Medicaid costs. In 2002, the county paid $13.6 million into the state pension system. In 2003, that figure rose to $55.3 million, and in 2004 it is projected to rise to $87.8 million. ''Within two years, there will have been an increase of 546 percent,'' said Arthur A. Gianelli, the deputy county executive for budget and finance. ''So in the midst of trying to recover the county's finances, we'll have to add $74 million to the budget to pay for employee pensions. We had structured the budget conservatively to account for unforeseen circumstances, but the pension increase absorbed nearly all of the funds that would have been available for contingency purposes.''
docs.abstract: Nassau and Suffolk Counties and municipalities across Long Island are crunching budgets in effort to deal with soaring pension and Medicaid costs; some municipalities have been able to budget for soaring expenses while others have been forced to borrow and still others are considering tax increases; graph (M)
docs.snippet: WHEN the Suozzi administration took office in January 2002, it tackled Nassau County's budget crisis by reducing the county workforce by 1,100, enacting efficiencies that saved $100 million and negotiating labor contracts that it said held the line...

docs.lead_paragraph: DOCTORS' groups, insurers and President Bush have vowed to continue their fight in 2004 to pass legislation that caps jury awards in medical malpractice suits. But there is another movement inching forward, and it, too, could have far-reaching consequences for injured patients. Slowly and quietly, the rules regarding expert witness testimony in medical malpractice cases have been changing: a handful of states have passed legislation in the last two years that generally requires physician experts to work in the same field as a defendant doctor, while professional doctors' groups are setting up committees to review the testimony of their members.
docs.abstract: Michelle Andrews column says changes in rules regarding expert witness testimony in medical malpractice are making malpractice harder to prove; many doctors, concerned that courts do not do enough to weed out physicians who make living testifying as expert witnesses, have become activists for curbs and closer scrutiny of expert testimony; some critics warn doctors are so desperate to cut malpractice costs that they seek to chip away at chance to present expert testimony; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Here now is the latest news from the Princeton University class of 1933, as reported by the class secretary, F. Tremaine Billings: Past president Curly Marsh is unbeatable. Still can't swallow and now has developed diabetes, but is holding his weight and getting around. . . . According to Dottie, Sam Loveland's memory is gone. Dottie visits him regularly and is not sure whether he knows her. . . . Maddy Haythe, having lost the sight in one eye after a tough fall, is cheerful and active.

headline.main: In Princetonian's Spare Telling, Class of '33 Drifts Into Winter

docs.abstract: Dr F Tremaine Billings, 91-year-old graduate of Princeton Univ's class of 1933, supplies Princeton Alumni Weekly with regular updates on his classmates; only 56 of 622 graduates remain, and many of those still living have debilitating ailments, but he tries to keep column as positive as he can without lapsing into euphemism or denial; excerpts from some of his columns; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Here now is the latest news from the Princeton University class of 1933, as reported by the class secretary, F. Tremaine Billings:    Past president Curly Marsh is unbeatable. Still can't swallow and now has developed diabetes, but is holding his...

docs.lead_paragraph: A popular prescription drug to prevent unwanted pregnancies is safe enough that it should be made available over the counter to the women who urgently need it, an advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration recommended last week. The F.D.A.'s commissioner, Mark McClellan, must now decide to accept or reject the finding, and faces an intense debate over the ethics of selling the morning-after pill, called Plan B, as if it were no different from aspirin, for example. But what about the scientific question? If the pill is so safe, and so important, why was it sold by prescription in the first place, as it has been since 1999?

headline.main: The Nation; There's a Blurry Line Between Rx and O.T.C.

docs.abstract: FDA decision-making on selling drugs by prescription or over-the-counter takes into account many factors that have nothing to do with science or patient safety, such as marketing and financial considerations, politics, doctors' concerns and consumer psychology; photo of late Sen Hubert Humphrey, onetime pharmacist who sponsored 1951 law authorizing FDA to classify drugs (M)
docs.snippet: A popular prescription drug to prevent unwanted pregnancies is safe enough that it should be made available over the counter to the women who urgently need it, an advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration recommended last week.     The...

docs.lead_paragraph: When I travel for work, department policy allows me to tip cabdrivers, bellmen, the bell captain and waitpersons (men, in most cases) but not maids (almost always women, and usually recent immigrants), as they are 'paid a salary.' Rather than argue the point, I usually submit two extra taxi receipts to cover tips to the maid. My actions are not totally correct, but aren't they less unethical than my company's policy? Anonymous, Chicago The caprice of your department's tipping policy and its inherent, if unintended, sexism and racism are undeniable. However, your tipping the housekeepers -- something you believe to be an ethical obligation -- is not contingent on your company's reimbursing you. If it is the right thing to do, it's still right even if it comes out of your pocket. This does not mean, however, that you may submit bogus cab receipts to get your boss to cover this expense. I think my boss should pay at least part of my health insurance, but that doesn't allow me to use fake cab receipts -- presumably for a ride from here to Neptune -- to get reimbursed.

headline.kicker: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 12-21-03: THE ETHICIST

docs.abstract: Randy Cohen's The Ethicist column answers readers' questions on whether someone traveling at company expense may submit bogus cab bills in order to be reimbursed for tips to hotel maid, which company will not cover, and whether healthy people should forgo getting flu shots if vaccine is in short supply (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Not long ago, a man who runs a construction company came to the White House to meet with a senior Bush administration official. He talked economic policy, then was asked how his business was going. He said things were going well. Orders were up. He'd revamped his I.T. system, and he'd re-engineered his production process so he'd been able to reduce his work force to 7,200 from 9,800.
docs.abstract: David Brooks Op-Ed column contends that US economy is doing well, but because of enormous productivity gains, it is not yet producing enough jobs to sharply reduce unemployment and ensure Pres Bush's re-election; maintains that administration officials hope, in second term, to let individuals control part of their Social Security pensions and perhaps even their medical savings accounts; says Ownership Society idea allows Bush to be centrist and conservative at same time (M)
